Issues.Title: refactor(core): remove unused i18n placeholder for projection
Issues.Body:
Runtime i18n logic doesn't distinguish `<ng-content>` tag placeholders and regular element tag
placeholders in i18n messages, so there is no need to have a special marker for projection-based
placeholders and element markers can be used instead.


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

Issues.Title: Recommendation clarification for Observables
Issues.Body:
### Description
I would like to ask the core developers to clarify/expand the following sentence in the documentation for [Observables](https://angular.io/guide/observables):  "_They are used frequently in Angular and are the recommended technique for event handling, **asynchronous programming**, and handling multiple values._".

**Problem:**
_asynchronous programming_ here is a little bit wide. In some cases it might be interpreted as "do not use promises at all" [1][2]. As this is an official documentation and people who start to dive into angular tend to read documentation as a single truth, I would like to reduce a number interpretations.

**important:** this issue is not about observables vs promises.

---
**[1]**: as for some people...
1. learning two concepts (promises/observables) is irrational as they can concentrate on a single concept (but as angular recommends to use observables, the choice is obvious);
2. `async` and `await` aren't in a comfort zone;
3. who has never worked with event driven APIs (example: node.js) (to get a feel for the difference in these concepts) is not clear when to use promises as the observable is more powerful (read: rxjs) and with canceling.

**[2]**: which is not the case according the angular codebase itself where we can find promises.

---

### Proposal
Add a new clarification describing why/when promises should (not) be used and (one of)
a. To remove _asynchronous programming_ from the mentioned paragraph.
b. Keep _asynchronous programming_

### URL:
https://angular.io/guide/observables

### Similars
- [When to use Observables and Promises in Angular](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55129131/when-to-use-observables-and-promises-in-angular?rq=1)
- [When to use Promise over observable?](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50269671/when-to-use-promise-over-observable)
and so on.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Recommendation clarification for Observables" (#39155)

Issues.Title: Be more accurate in minimal supported browser versions
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

The supported browser versions listed [here](https://github.com/angular/angular/edit/master/aio/content/guide/browser-support.md) aren't that much accurate and make hard the explanations to bring to the client if it needs to upgrade each collaborator's browser. 


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

### What's the affected URL?**
https://angular.io/guide/browser-support
<sub>(source: https://github.com/angular/angular/edit/master/aio/content/guide/browser-support.md)</sub>

### Expected vs Actual Behavior**
<!-- If applicable please describe the difference between the expected and actual behavior after following the repro steps. -->
What could be nice would be to tell a range or a minimal supported version for the given Angular release (as it's done for Angular v2 (c.f. screenshot down below).

E.g.: for Chrome or Firefox, `latest` is really not accurate since it's hard with that to know if the client's browser matches or not a valid browser version for the project's Angular version.

## üì∑Screenshot
<!-- Often a screenshot can help to capture the issue better than a long description. -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èupload a screenshot:-->

Current documentation (not accurate):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5319267/95311645-2be8fe00-088e-11eb-80e3-47385bf88ce3.png)

Old Angular v2 documentation (more accurate):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5319267/95311702-4622dc00-088e-11eb-875f-c31af5c7104c.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Be more accurate in minimal supported browser versions" (#39152)

Issues.Title: fix(router): Allow undefined inputs on routerLink
Issues.Body: ## PR Checklist Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements: - [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit - [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features) - [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features) ## PR Type What kind of change does this PR introduce? - [x] Bugfix - [ ] Feature - [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables) - [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes) - [ ] Build related changes - [ ] CI related changes - [ ] Documentation content changes - [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes - [ ] Other... Please describe: ## What is the current behavior? When compiling in the most strict mode, the following will throw error, but it is should be valid: ```html some link ``` The error would be similar to: ``` ERROR in foo.component.html:2:52 - error TS2322: Type 'null' is not assignable to type 'string'. 2 some link ``` ## What is the new behavior? This make it coherent with typing of Router.createUrlTree to which those inputs are directly forwarded to. And hence it allow to pass `undefined`, `null` or a value to the routerLink directive. ## Does this PR introduce a breaking change? - [ ] Yes - [x] No ## Other information
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(router): Allow undefined inputs on routerLink" (#39151)

"@angular/animations": "~10.1.4", "@angular/common": "~10.1.4", "@angular/compiler": "~10.1.4", "@angular/core": "~10.1.4", "@angular/forms": "~10.1.4", "@angular/platform-browser": "~10.1.4", "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "~10.1.4", "@angular/router": "~10.1.4", "rxjs": "~6.6.0", "tslib": "^2.0.0", "zone.js": "~0.10.2" ### Description Dev server error is present when template error is fixed ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction install the latest version of @angular/cli I am using ``` "@angular/cli": "~10.1.4", ``` create a brand new app like ``` ng new my-new-app ``` In app.component.html, copy and paste the following line inside of the main content div: ```

Hello World!

``` Change the first double quote to single quote to cause the template error. Then change it back to double quote to fix it. In the terminal, these errors are shown: ``` ERROR in src/app/app.module.ts:9:5 - error NG6001: The class 'AppComponent' is listed in the declarations of the NgModule 'AppModule', but is not a directive, a component, or a pipe. Either remove it from the NgModule's declarations, or add an appropriate Angular decorator. 9 AppComponent ~~~~~~~~~~~~ src/app/app.component.ts:8:14 8 export class AppComponent { ~~~~~~~~~~~~ 'AppComponent' is declared here. src/app/app.component.html:417:25 - error NG8002: Can't bind to 'ngSwitch' since it isn't a known property of 'div'. 417
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ src/app/app.component.ts:5:16 5 templateUrl: './app.component.html', ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Error occurs in the template of component AppComponent. src/app/app.component.html:535:1 - error NG8001: 'router-outlet' is not a known element: 1. If 'router-outlet' is an Angular component, then verify that it is part of this module. 2. If 'router-outlet' is a Web Component then add 'CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA' to the '@NgModule.schemas' of this component to suppress this message. 535 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ src/app/app.component.ts:5:16 5 templateUrl: './app.component.html', ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Error occurs in the template of component AppComponent. ``` You can read more about issue submission guidelines here: ## üåç Your Environment It's a brand new angular app as of 10/6/2020: "dependencies": { "@angular/animations": "~10.1.4", "@angular/common": "~10.1.4", "@angular/compiler": "~10.1.4", "@angular/core": "~10.1.4", "@angular/forms": "~10.1.4", "@angular/platform-browser": "~10.1.4", "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "~10.1.4", "@angular/router": "~10.1.4", "rxjs": "~6.6.0", "tslib": "^2.0.0", "zone.js": "~0.10.2" }, "devDependencies": { "@angular-devkit/build-angular": "~0.1001.4", "@angular/cli": "~10.1.4", "@angular/compiler-cli": "~10.1.4", "@types/node": "^12.11.1", "@types/jasmine": "~3.5.0", "@types/jasminewd2": "~2.0.3", "codelyzer": "^6.0.0", "jasmine-core": "~3.6.0", "jasmine-spec-reporter": "~5.0.0", "karma": "~5.0.0", "karma-chrome-launcher": "~3.1.0", "karma-coverage-istanbul-reporter": "~3.0.2", "karma-jasmine": "~4.0.0", "karma-jasmine-html-reporter": "^1.5.0", "protractor": "~7.0.0", "ts-node": "~8.3.0", "tslint": "~6.1.0", "typescript": "~4.0.2" }

Issues.Title: Improve Observables Testing documentation
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description of the problem

Observables are a huge part of Angular.

Currently, the testing docs have examples on how to test Observable related code scattered across docs and we don't have a dedicated place to learn about Observable testing. 

A lot of examples are scattered around the docs and suggest either testing observables by subscribing (without unsubscribing BTW which is another issue), or [showing how to test using marble tests](https://angular.io/guide/testing-components-scenarios), (and doing it only in the "components section" although it's not limited only to components).
And by that it seems like we're jumping from the "easiest thing possible" straight to "having to know hot, cold, TestScheduler and look at all these signs!" type of tests (marble testing).

When there is a much simpler way to test Observables.
It pretty new but very effective (according to people who used it in real life) and it's called: 

### [`observer-spy`](https://github.com/hirezio/observer-spy) 

I created it a few months ago with the aim of reducing complexity when it comes to testing observables.

So although I'm biased, I waited a few months to see whether this open source library actually provides value to devs other than my clients before I thought about suggesting to add it to the docs.

So far it seems that it makes people lives' easier.

For example, here are some of the responses I got since it got published - 

---

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1430726/95263162-0cbe8200-0836-11eb-9d78-45a7e64c38f7.png)

---

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1430726/95263462-7dfe3500-0836-11eb-8aca-0d9283b2d66b.png)

---

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1430726/95263672-d1708300-0836-11eb-8fb2-2906105e18f7.png)

---

Observer spies are much less complicated than marble testing and don't require testing implementation details like knowing exactly how many frames passed between values (which normally you only care about the values and their order, rather than the time between them). 

I believe marble testing should be the last topic we cover on Observable Testing to reduce the friction newcomers have when trying to learn Angular + testing, and to supply them with the simplest tools first before jumping into the more complicated ones üòÖ 

### Proposed Solution - a Dedicated "Observables Testing" Document

Because Observables are a cross cutting topic which can be found in all Angular types (services, components, etc), I believe it should have it's own document called "Observables Testing".

In there we should start by showing the simplest way (subscribing to get a value), then showing how to use observer-spies and with `subscribeSpyTo` and `autoUnsubscribe` (not to leave any leaks), the move to show how to auto-spy on dependencies which return observables and lastly - show how to test using marble tests. 

#### The proposed table of contents:

1. An Observable Under Test - the easiest way
2. Testing multiple values - using observer spies
3. Faking dependencies with Observable returning methods
4. Marble Tests

I believe this would make the whole notion of Observable testing much easier to digest and get easy wins in both Angular and also NgRx code (like testing effects) and will help lower the entry barrier for testing Observables.  

Let me know what you think. If we move forward, I could create a draft of the content and work with your documentation team to include it on Angular.io.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Improve Observables Testing documentation" (#39144)

##### Bug Fixes

-   **common:** add boolean to valid json for testing ([#​37893](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/37893)) ([3c474ec](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/commit/3c474ec)), closes [#​20690](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/20690)
-   **core:** use single quotes for relative link resolution migration to align with style guide ([#​39070](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/39070)) ([8894706](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/commit/8894706))

-   **forms:** include null in .parent of abstract control ([#​32671](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/32671)) ([f4f1bcc](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/commit/f4f1bcc)), closes [#​16999](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/16999)
-   **language-service:** [Ivy] hybrid visitor should not locate let keyword ([#​39061](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/39061)) ([70e13dc](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/commit/70e13dc))
-   **router:** properly assign ExtraOptions to Router in RouterTestingModule ([#​39096](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/39096)) ([d8c0534](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/commit/d8c0534)), closes [#​23347](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/23347)

##### Features

-   **compiler-cli:** support getting resource dependencies for a source file ([#​38048](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/38048)) ([5dbf357](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/commit/5dbf357))
-   **forms:** add migration for AbstractControl.parent accesses ([#​39009](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/39009)) ([aeec223](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/commit/aeec223)), closes [#​32671](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/32671)
-   **language-service:** Add getDefinitionAndBoundSpan (go to definition) ([#​39101](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/39101)) ([3975dd9](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/commit/3975dd9))
-   **language-service:** add quick info for inline templates in ivy ([#​39060](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/39060)) ([904adb7](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/commit/904adb7))

##### BREAKING CHANGES

-   **forms:** Directives in the `@angular/forms` package used to have `any[]` as a type of `validators` and
    `asyncValidators` arguments in constructors. Now these arguments are properly typed, so if your
    code relies on directive constructor types it may require some updates to improve type safety.
-   **forms:** Type of AbstractFormControl.parent now includes null

`null` is now included in the types of .parent. If you don't already have a check for this case,
the TypeScript compiler might compain. A v11 migration exists which adds the not-null assertion
operator where necessary.

In an unlikely case your code was testing the parnet against undefined with sitrct equality,
you'll need to change this to `=== null` instead, since the parent is not explicily initialized
with `null` instead of being left `undefined`.

#### 10.1.5 (2020-10-07)

-   **compiler:** Recover on malformed keyed reads and keyed writes ([#​39004](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/39004)) ([f50313f](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/commit/f50313f)), closes [#​38596](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/issues/38596)

Issues.Title: Referencing 'assets' folder images in published web app
Issues.Body:
Hi,

i've read a lot of reported issues regarding '**assets**' folder, but still can't figure out, how to make it work in my simple case.

So, I publish _Angular 10_ app using the following command:
**ng build --configuration azuredev --base-href /CentralTools/ --deploy-url /CentralTools/**
onto _IIS_ into '**CentralTools**' folder accessible as corresponding _web application_.

And my logo, that is referenced by 3rd party CSS as follows:
**:root{--logo:url(/assets/images/logo/logo-light.png)**

is of course not found, because '**CentralTools**' is ignored - it looks for the image in root folder of _IIS_ server:
**.....azure.com/assets/images/logo/logo-light.png 404**
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Referencing 'assets' folder images in published web app" (#19000)

Issues.Title: Deprecate several dev-server builder options
Issues.Body:
**refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): deprecate a number of dev-server options**
With this change we deprecate a number of dev-server builder options which proxied to the browser builder. This pattern also wrongly assumes that 3rd party browser builders also support all these options.

Configure the below deprecated options directly in the browser builder target options instead.

- aot
- sourceMap
- deployurl
- baseHref
- vendorChunk
- commonChunk
- optimization
- progress


**refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): deprecate hmrWarning and servePathDefaultWarning options**
With this change we deprecate servePathDefaultWarning and hmrWarning which no longer has an effect.

Using any unsupported deploy-url or base-href serve path value will result in a hard warning.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Deprecate several dev-server builder options" (#18988)

Issues.Title: Angular cli doc does not mention how budget is calculated.
Issues.Body:
I recently came across a [Stackoverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/q/59246888/3503019) about `Angular budgets throw error but files do not reach size`. After some research I found that `angular cli` uses chunks size, not assets size to issue budget error or warnings. Look at [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/64188214/3503019) answer in the same question. If that's true, the angular cli document should make it clear -

**Update [this doc](https://angular.io/guide/build#configuring-size-budgets) with below details** -

1. How angular cli calculates bundle size? Is it before the optimization is done?
2. If yes, why it does not consider final assets that get generated in `dist` folder?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Angular cli doc does not mention how budget is calculated." (#18989)

Issues.Title: Building an application automatically watch for libraries changes
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [x] build
- [x] serve
### Description
Whe working in an Angular workspace,
you have to run `ng build [lib] --watch` on all libraries and then `ng build [app] --watch`
to detect the changes and rebuild the application with the latest libraries changes.

### Describe the solution you'd like
‚Ä¢ A flag (`--watchLibraries=opts`?) to automatically build & watch libraries when running `ng build [app] --watch`
or
‚Ä¢ An option in angular.json to make it dependent on the configuration.

`opts=true|false|noFirstBuild`:
true/false: activate / deactivate the functionnality.
noFirstBuild: to prevent having to compile lots of libraries each time you run the command, you can choose to only build them if they changed after the application has been built.

How to detect the libraries:
Using `angular.json#projects.[project].projectType` (= library)

### Describe alternatives you've considered
npm scripts, but each time you add a library you need to add it in the scripts.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Building an application automatically watch for libraries changes" (#18985)

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): fix recursion in `findNodes` ast utils
Issues.Body:
### Problem
`findNodes` is not recursive when `recursive` flag is set.
### Solution
Pass down `recursive` flag when  calling `findNodes` recursively.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@schematics/angular): fix recursion in `findNodes` ast utils" (#18980)

Issues.Title: Inline SourceMap Option
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

Related issue: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/13543

### Command 

- [X] build
- [X] serve

### Description

Please consider a inline source map option again. It's just one more option. It's easy to implement in the Angular webpack config. It's just one attribute. See [docs](https://angular.io/cli/build).

### Describe the solution you'd like

 I suggest option `sourceMapType` or a new value.
Why not? Just add `devtool: 'inline-source-map'` to the `webpack.config.js` if this option is set.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

I don't want additional dependencies, plugins or hacks. Just an official option in the build CLI. Please üôè 
Btw. `ngx-build-plus` does not work. I don't want to rely on these 3rd party libs. Another risky build breaker.
It's really just a minor change in Angular CLI, or not?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Inline SourceMap Option" (#18975)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/cli): add blank line in migration commit message
Issues.Body:
When using the `-C` option of `update`, the commit message of the migration is missing a blank line between the subject and body. 

For example,

Previously was missing blank line after the commit subject:
```
@angular/cli migration - rename-browserslist-config
Update Browserslist configuration file name to '.browserslistrc' from deprecated 'browserslist'.
```

Now fixed:
```
@angular/cli migration - rename-browserslist-config

Update Browserslist configuration file name to '.browserslistrc' from deprecated 'browserslist'.
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular/cli): add blank line in migration commit message" (#18971)

Issues.Title: fix(material/slider): some screen readers announcing long decimal values
Issues.Body:
It looks like some screen readers announce the value of a slider by calculating the percentage themselves using the `aria-valuemin`, `aria-valuemax` and `aria-valuenow`. The problem is that they don't round down the decimals so for a slider between 0 and 1 with a step of 0.1, they end up reading out values like 0.20000068. These changes work around the issue by setting `aria-valuetext` to the same value that we shown in the thumb which we truncate ourselves.

Fixes #20719.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(material/slider): some screen readers announcing long decimal values" (#20721)

Issues.Title: bug(MatCheckbox/MatSlideToggle/DragDrop): Some components don't work in mobile for upgraded angularjs material to angular material project
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

I've created a stackblitz for this: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-qhprlc
You can view the issue in mobile: https://angular-ivy-qhprlc.stackblitz.io/

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create an angularjs to angular upgrade project which includes both angularjs material and angular material.
2. Add a MatCheckbox, MaxSlideToggle, or DragDrop list.
 
#### Expected Behavior

I expect the checkbox to check when tapped.

I expect the slidetoggle to toggle when tapped.

I expect to be able to sort the list when taping and dragging on an item.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

MatCheckbox will display the ripple effect, but not become checked when tapped.

MatSlideToggle also displays the ripple effect, but does not toggle when tapped.

The dragdrop list will pick up the item and move it when tapped and drag. Releasing the tap does not drop the time. Tapping again in the list will move the item originally selected to the new place tapped. Tapping outside of the list will drop the item where it was released.

Note this a further investigation of issues #19466 and #17146, which I've finally been able to get a repo on stackblitz for.
https://github.com/angular/components/issues/19466
https://github.com/angular/components/issues/17146

#### Environment

- Angular: 7.2.8, 8.2.7, 9.1.0, 10.1.4
- CDK/Material: 7.2, 8.2, 9.2, 10.2.3
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows, Android
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(MatCheckbox/MatSlideToggle/DragDrop): Some components don't work in mobile for upgraded angularjs material to angular material project" (#20725)

Issues.Title: fix(cdk/drag-drop): references to SVG not working inside preview
Issues.Body:
When we create a drag preview we clone the original element, move it to the bottom of the `body`, set it to `display: none` and clear all `id` attributes from the clone. As a result, SVG references inside the element break, because the source node is invisible.

These changes resolve the issue by moving the original element outside the layout and making it transparent, instead of using `display: none`.

Fixes #20720.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(cdk/drag-drop): references to SVG not working inside preview" (#20742)

Issues.Title: help(Mat Datepicker): Do not autocomplete date when focus is out
Issues.Body:
#### What are you trying to do?

I've setup a datepicker and I want to type 1 and focus out the input and keep the 1. But instead the datepicker gets autocompleted with 1/1/2001. My client doesn't like that!!

`<mat-form-field appearance="fill">
  <mat-label>Choose a date</mat-label>
  <input matInput [matDatepicker]="picker">
  <mat-datepicker-toggle matSuffix [for]="picker"></mat-datepicker-toggle>
  <mat-datepicker #picker></mat-datepicker>
</mat-form-field>`

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

Pressing tab or leaving the focus out of the input autocompletes the date and I dont want that

#### Reproduction

The issue is easily reproduced in the same page of Angular Material documentation in browsers like Chrome, Safari, IE11, etc
https://material.angular.io/components/datepicker/overview


Steps to reproduce:
1. Go to https://material.angular.io/components/datepicker/overview
2.  Find a datepicker
3. Type 1
4. Press tab or focus the input out
5. See how date gets autocompleted with 1/1/2001
6. My expectation is if I type 1 then leave it as 1. We take care of validations.
  
#### Environment

All browsers, All devices, All OS.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "help(Mat Datepicker): Do not autocomplete date when focus is out" (#20741)

Issues.Title: feat(mat-checkbox): add functionality for adding custom icons for mat checkbox states
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

A user should be able to set an own icon for e.g. the indeterminate state. It would be nice if you can set a SVG file in CSS or register your icon in the matIconRegistry and then give the user the functionality to set the icon for the states after that.

#### Use Case

A use case would be when someone wants to use his own icon set. I have currently a project where I have got an icon which looks similar to the material but with some changes (checkmark is thicker and the border-radius was changed).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feat(mat-checkbox): add functionality for adding custom icons for mat checkbox states" (#20733)

Issues.Title: Scrollblock for Dialogs and Bottom Sheets: Always add 'cdk-global-scrollblock' class to the root when opening a bottom sheet or dialog
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

When opening a dialog/bottom sheet the 'cdk-global-scrollblock' is applied to the html tag, preventing the background to be scrollable through the modal. According to the answer of @crisbeto "The dialog won't try to block scrolling if the page isn't scrollable" - https://github.com/angular/components/issues/16864

But actually I have a use case (with bottom sheets), where it would be useful to always apply the class.

#### Use Case

I have a bottom sheet menu, from which I can open other bottom sheets. The first (menu) bottom sheet applies 'cdk-global-scrollblock'. When the other one is opened, the background is not scrollable anymore (because of the blocking class), so it removes it again, making the page in the background scrollable again.

My use case is only with bottom sheets, but since the similar issue, https://github.com/angular/components/issues/16864, describes the same problem, I assume dialogs and bottom sheets work the same in this behaviour. Correct me, if I am wrong.

#### Feature Request (Summary)

If 'cdk-global-scrollblock' is applied and a new bottom sheet/dialog is opened, the class should stay.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Scrollblock for Dialogs and Bottom Sheets: Always add 'cdk-global-scrollblock' class to the root when opening a bottom sheet or dialog" (#20734)

Issues.Title: feat(MatDatepickerModule): Inclusive End Date on date range selection
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Currently when using the new date range picker component, the end date is exlucded from the date selection. It would be helpful to have an option to set the date picker to be inclusive of the end day.

#### Use Case

A user is looking for something on a single specific day, so they may set the start and end dates in the range to the same value, expecting that the range would be set for that day only.

Currently if you select the same start and end date in your range, it's essentially a range of 0 seconds. The component allows this, but it doesnt really make sense.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feat(MatDatepickerModule): Inclusive End Date on date range selection" (#20736)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-table): Filtering a mat-table with inputs using ngModel render the same row
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/fork/components-issue
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ngmodel-material-table?file=app/table-basic-example.html

Steps to reproduce:
1. Type in the filter "Hello" > 2 entries should display with correct data
2. Add in the filter a number 2, the text "Hello2" should be in the filter > 1 entry should display in the table
3. Add in the filter letter 'x', the text "Hello2x" should be in the filter > no entries should display in the table
4. Delete 'x' and '2', the text "Hello" should be in the filter > 2 entries are shown displaying the same duplicated information, Filtered data json at the bottom shows the correct data, that is not displayed in the table.

The rendered data should be the same as the filtered data, displaying the 2 rows with the correct data

#### Actual Behavior

#### Environment

- CDK/Material:
- Browser(s):
Chrome
Firefox
